Introduction

Renal development is a complex, highly regulated process involving multiple embryologic structures that contribute to the formation of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.  A thorough understanding of renal embryology is essential for the diagnosis and management of congenital renal anomalies.

Overview



Renal development begins in early embryogenesis with the formation of the nephrogenic cord from intermediate mesoderm in the lower thoracic, lumbar, and sacral regions.  Renal development occurs in a cranial-to-caudal sequence and progresses through 3 sequential stages (

figure 1
), as follows:



  • Pronephros (weeks 3-4):  Derived from intermediate mesoderm in the cervical region.  The pronephros is composed of 7-10 groups of nephrotomes, or rudimentary, nonfunctional excretory units that regress before the end of the fourth week of gestation.  The pronephric ducts persist temporarily and initiate formation of the mesonephric duct.
  • Mesonephros (weeks 4-8):  Derived from intermediate mesoderm in the thoracolumbar region.  The mesonephros is composed of primitive renal corpuscles that drain into the mesonephric duct.  The mesonephros regresses in females but persists as the wolffian ducts in males, giving rise to the ductus deferens and epididymis.
  • Metanephros (weeks 5 to birth):  Derived from intermediate mesoderm in the lumbosacral region.  Development of the metanephros begins with the formation of the ureteric bud, an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct near its entrance into the cloaca.  The ureteric bud induces formation of the metanephric blastema from the intermediate mesoderm of the sacral region.  Reciprocal inductive signaling between the ureteric bud and the metanephric blastema induces their differentiation into structures of the upper urinary tract (
    figure 2
    ):
    • Metanephric blastema:  Gives rise to the renal parenchyma, including the glomeruli, proximal convoluted tubules, loops of Henle, distal convoluted tubules, and Bowman capsules.
    • Ureteric bud:  Gives rise to the collecting system, including the collecting tubules and ducts, major and minor calyces, renal pelvis, and ureter.

Ascent of the kidneys



The bilateral metanephroi develop in the pelvis and ascend to a more cranial position in the retroperitoneal cavity near the adrenal glands because of the disproportionately rapid growth of the caudal portion of the embryo.  In the pelvis, the metanephroi are supplied by a pelvic branch of the aorta.  As the metanephroi ascend, they are supplied by a series of arteries that originate from progressively more cranial positions along the aorta.  The caudal arteries generally degenerate as the metanephroi ascend.

Development of the ureters, bladder, and urethra



During weeks 4-7 of gestation, the cloaca is partitioned anteriorly into the urogenital sinus and posteriorly into the hindgut.  The cranial urogenital sinus forms most of the bladder; the caudal mesonephric ducts are incorporated into the bladder wall and form the trigone of the bladder.  Moving caudally, the pelvic urogenital sinus gives rise to the prostatic and membranous parts of the urethra in males.

Clinical correlation



A thorough understanding of renal embryology is essential for the diagnosis and management of congenital renal anomalies.  Failed progression through any of these steps can result in a unique congenital anomaly with important clinical implications.  The various congenital renal anomalies are discussed in a separate dedicated article.

Summary



Renal development is a complex, dynamic process involving multiple embryologic structures that contribute to the formation of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.  During early embryogenesis, 3 distinct systems develop in a cranial-to-caudal sequence: the pronephros, mesonephros, and metanephros.  The metanephros gives rise to the definitive kidney, and abnormal development can result in a variety of congenital renal anomalies.
